title: Former Tory MP storms off from Naga Munchetty interview
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Former Tory MP Harvey Proctor stormed out of a BBC Breakfast interview this morning after claiming he was prevented from speaking.

Mr Proctor was talking presenter Naga Munchetty about the disgraced Operation Midland, in which millions was spent investigating fake claims of a paedophile ring in Westminster.

Asked how it felt to be caught up in the botched inquiry, he said: ‘I lost my job, my home and my repute as a result of a fantasist who were believed by the Metropolitan Police.’

He then began to criticise the Metropolitan Police and Commissioner Cressida Dick, to which Ms Munchetty responded to by trying to read out a statement from the force.

She and Mr Proctor talked across each other, causing him to say: ‘By talking across me you’re not really doing what the BBC should do, and that is to give a right to comment.’

Harvey Proctor walked out of the interview with Naga Munchetty (Picture: BBC)

Ms Munchetty continued to try and read the statement, explaining: ‘I want to get to how this has impacted you, but I need to do my job as well.’

Mr Proctor accused the presenter of not letting him speak, which she denied.

She said: ‘I also need to give a right of reply rather than letting you say things that are potentially incorrect.’

The former MP then decided to bring the interview to an end, walking off camera and saying: ‘I am sorry, I am not having this.’

After his departure Ms Munchetty said: ‘I think what was made very clear there is the impact that this investigation has had on his life.’

The interview is the second time Ms Munchetty has hit the headlines in recent weeks (Picture: BBC)

Mr Proctor was one of several high-profile figures named by Carl Beech, who was granted anonymity under the name ‘Nick’, as part of the alleged Westminster paedophile ring.

Beech, 51, was later jailed for 18 years for 12 counts of perverting the course of justice, one of fraud, and for several child sexual offences.
